page.title: Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution

revisions.rev:
{{Cleanup|date=April 2011}} The '''trials and judicial hearings following the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]]''' were a series of legal moves to establish accountability among the various [[Egypt]]ian government officials and prominent businessmen.
A series of arrests and travel bans was imposed on high profile figures following the ousting of the former president [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s regime. These were based on several charges: causing the death of as many as 800 demonstrators;<ref name="Detention">{{cite news|author=|url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/14/world/middleeast/14egypt.html?_r=1 |title= Prosecutors Order Mubarak and Sons Held |work=The New York Times |date=13 March 2011|accessdate=13 April 2011 |first1=David D. |last1=Kirkpatrick |first2=Liam |last2=Stack}}</ref> the injury of around 5,000 demonstrators; as well as [[embezzlement]], [[profiteering]], [[money laundering]] and [[human rights abuses]]. Notable figures arrested included Mubarak, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak|Suzanne]], his sons [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] and [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former Housing Minister [[Ahmed El Maghrabi]], former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]], and the former secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Arrest warrants were also issued for some public figures who had already left the country during the start of the revolution, mostly on charges of financial misappropriations. These included the former minster of trade and industry, [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], and [[Hussein Salem]], a business tycoon.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
Mubarak's ousting was followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians.<ref>{{cite news|author=Phillip Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-03-23 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Mahmoud Muslim |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=Mostafa Al Fiqi: a big personality in the presidency confirmed that Â«MubarakÂ» will not run and his son would be the alternative |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> These included the former speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former speaker of the higher legislative body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak â then what? - Politics â Egypt â Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§Ù ØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ Ù ØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Trials of the accused officials started on March 5, 2011, when the former interior minster of Egypt, [[Habib el-Adli]], appeared before the Giza Criminal Court in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/27/adly_judgment.aspx |title=5 Ù Ø§Ø±Ø³.. Ø¨Ø¯Ø¡ Ù Ø­Ø§ÙÙ Ø© Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ Ø£Ù Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-02-27 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The trials of el-Adli and other public figures are expected to take a long time.
==Background to the trials== ===Allegations of corruption=== [[Political corruption]] in the Mubarak administration's [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Interior Ministry]] had risen dramatically due to the increased power over the institutional system necessary to prolong the presidency.<ref name="Egypt after Mubarak">{{Cite book|last=Rutherford|first=Bruce|title=Egypt after Mubarak: Liberalism, Islam, and Democracy in the Arab World|publisher=[[Princeton University Press]]|year=2008|month=November|isbn= 0-6911-3665-3}}</ref> The rise to power of prominent businessmen in the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP), in the government, and in the People's Assembly (Egyptian Parliament) led to waves of anger during the tenure of Prime Minister's [[Ahmed Nazif]]'s government. An example is [[Ahmed Ezz]]'s [[Monopoly|monopolization]] of the Egyptian steel industry by holding more than 60 percent of the market share.<ref name="Emerging Egypt 2007">{{Cite book|last=|first=|title=The Report: Egypt 2007|publisher=[[Oxford Business Group]]|year=2007|month=January|isbn= 1-9023-3957-6}}</ref> American professor Alaadin Elaasar, a noted Egyptian biographer, estimates that the Mubarak family is worth somewhere between $50 to $70 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/aladdin-elaasar/egyptians-rise-against-th_b_815520.html |title=Egyptians Rise Against Their Pharoah |work=[[Huffington Post]] |last=Elaasar |first=Aladdin |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/egypt-mubarak-family-accumulated-wealth-days-military/story?id=12821073&page=2|title=Egypt's Mubarak Likely to Retain Vast Wealth|publisher=''[[ABC News]]''|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
The perceptions of corruption, and its beneficiaries, being limited to businessmen with ties to the NDP had created a picture "where wealth fuels political power and political power buys wealth."<ref>{{cite web|author=Inside Story |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/programmes/insidestory/2011/02/201128111236245847.html |title=How did Egypt become so corrupt? - Inside Story |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> *The wealth of Ahmed Ezz, the former NDP Organisation Secretary, is estimated to be 18 billion [[Egyptian pound]]s.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions">{{cite web|url=http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90033584?Obama%20optimistic%20about%20Egypt%20as%20negotiators%20make%20concessions|title=Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions|publisher=AHN|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> *The wealth of former Housing Minister, Ahmed el-Maghraby, is estimated to be more than 11 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> *The wealth of former Minister of Tourism [[Zuhair Garrana]] is estimated to be 13 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> *The wealth of former Minister of Trade and Industry, Rashid Mohamed Rashid, is estimated to be 12 billion Egyptian pounds;<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" /> *The wealth of former Interior Minister Habib al-Adly is estimated to be 8 billion Egyptian pounds.<ref name="Obama optimistic about Egypt as negotiators make concessions" />
During the 2010 [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|Egyptian parliamentary election]] opposition groups complained of harassment and fraud perpetrated by the government. As a result, opposition and civil society activists called for election reforms with changes to a [[National Association for Change#Platform|number of legal]] and [[National Association for Change#Goals|constitutional provisions]].
In 2010 the [[Transparency International]]'s [[Corruption Perceptions Index]] report assessed Egypt with a CPI score of 3.1 (with 10 being clean and 0 being totally corrupt), based on perceptions of the degree of corruption from business people and country analysts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.transparency.org/policy_research/surveys_indices/cpi/2010/results|title=CPI 2010 table|publisher=[[Transparency International]]|accessdate=26 October 2010}}</ref>
===Allegations of human rights abuses=== On March 5-6, 2011, numerous [[State Security Investigations Service|Egyptian State Security]] buildings were stormed by demonstrators after eyewitnesses reported that officials were shredding and burning documents which could potentially serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org">{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/march/5/37549 |title=Ø¨Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯ÙÙ ÙØ§ÙØµÙØ±..Ø£Ù Ù Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø¨Ù Ø¯ÙÙØ© ÙØµØ± Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø§Ù Ù ÙØ§ÙØªØ­ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙÙ Ù Ø§ ØªØ¨ÙÙ Ù Ù Ù Ø³ØªÙØ¯Ø§Øª Ø¯Ø§Ø®ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-05 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices, including the Cairo Downtown office (Lazoghly), the 6 October city office, and offices in [[Damanhour]], [[Nasr City]], [[Marsa Matrouh]] and [[Alexandria]].<ref name="ahram.org.eg">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66174.aspx |title=Revealing the hidden in State Security |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in these state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289708 |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ | Ø¸â¦Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â± Ø¢Â«Ø·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ·Â©Ø¢Â» Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â° Ø¸â¦Ø·Â±Ø¸â¦Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø¸â |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The demonstrators reportedly found evidence to support the widely accepted allegation of human rights abuses by Egyptian State Security. Egyptian newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]'' reported that the Damanhour office was perhaps the most panic provoking, as prison cells with electrocution equipment were found in close proximity to a secret graveyard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66081.aspx |title=The fall of the security of the state: The army receive the headquarters and discovered a secret grave rooms and a torture chamber electric |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
==Cases pertaining to public events== ===Public disorder=== {{Refimprove|section|reason=Many of the refs are non-English, mainly Ahram.org.eg|date=April 2011}} Numerous incidents of public disorder occurred from the start of the uprising. On January 28 the police withdrew from the streets of Egypt following break-ins to a number of prisons. Prison guards allegedly allowed and aided the escape of inmates. On February 2, a day that was dubbed the "Battle of the Camel", pro-government activists on camel- and horse-back stormed [[Tahrir Square]] in Downtown Cairo, where anti-regime demonstrators had set up camp, attacking them with [[Molotov cocktails]], stones, chipped marble, swords and other weapons. This confrontation resulted in the deaths of 91 demonstrators and the injury of several hundreds.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67082.aspx |title=Abdul Nasser Al Jabri transfered under heavy guard for interrogation |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The government appointed a fact-finding panel to investigate the cause of these incidents, headed by judge Adel Koura.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|author=Mohammed El-Sayyid Saleh |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289996 |title=Â«Almasry AlyoumÂ» get important information from the report of the "fact-finding" Committee about the lawlessness |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
The prosecution reported that, upon examining the sites where demonstrators were shot at, empty bullet-casings were found on the rooftops of buildings surrounding Tahrir Square, including the [[American University of Cairo]] (AUC). The AUC was closed at that time and it is believed that armed officers and regime loyalists had stormed the buildings and shot at the demonstrators. A similar scenario was reported in the area surrounding the Ministry of Interior in Cairo, where demonstrators were shot at from its roof. On March 10 [[Ismail el-Shaer]], the former security chief of Cairo, was interviewed by prosecutors regarding these incidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/10/37850 |title=Ø¥Ø³Ù Ø§Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ø§Ø¹Ø± ÙÙ Ø«Ù ÙÙØªØ­ÙÙÙ Ø£Ù Ø§Ù Ø£Ù Ù Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙ Ø§ØªÙØ§Ù Ø§Øª ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙ ØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-10 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> This was followed by the arrest of former Egyptian deputy interior minster Adly Fayed, chief of state security Hassan Abdulrahman, and chief of central security Ahmed Ramzy. All three were placed in custody for 15 days beginning on March 11.
Interrogation started the next day. ''Al-Ahram'' reported that a CD containing recordings of telephone conversations between [[Habib el-Adly]] and Ahmed Ramzy was examined as evidence. ''Al-Ahram'' also stated that Ramzy received orders from el-Adly to use live ammunition against anti-regime demonstrators. Ramzy denied this, but admitted that he ordered the use of rubber bullets and tear gas. He also stated that el-Adly ordered the withdrawal of the whole police force from the streets on the evening of January 28 only after the [[Military of Egypt|Egyptian military]] assumed responsibility. Ramzy claimed that this decision was made to avoid further confrontation between the police and the public. His account was supported by statements from Adly Fayed.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/66964.aspx |title=Imprisonment of four major heads of the Interior |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date=2010-09-07 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
Ismail El-Shaer was also investigated for allegations of ordering the use of weapons against demonstrators and for causing public disorder, which he denied. He was also accused of being the driver in the widely publicized "van incident", in which a police van intentionally rammed into a large group of demonstrators. El-Shaer denied that as well and stated that he was in his office at the time of the incident.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
On the day following the arrest and initial interrogation of el-Shaer, Ramzy, Fayed and Abdulrahman it was announced that the fact-finding panel headed by Judge Adel Koura has submitted four reports to the Egyptian prosecutor-general. Koura refused to name any officials who might have been legally charged with causing the death of protesters, but stated that the police force is not permitted to use live ammunition without authorization from the interior minster, whose decision must be approved by the country's political leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67070.aspx |title=Officers: Police fired on demonstrators because of the political leadership and Al-Adli's decision |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
The events of February 2 also led to allegations that members of the NDP funded and coordinated the activities of the regime loyalists who attacked demonstrators in Tahrir. The investigations of the fact-finding panel confirmed that two MPs from the NDP were involved. Both were named by ''Al-Ahram'' as [[Youssef Khatab]] and [[Abdulnasser el-Gabri]] and they were arrested on March 10.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
On March 21 the fact finding panel submitted its final report to the military council in charge of Egypt. ''Al-Ahram'' reported some of the findings from this report, including that 685 demonstrators were killed and approximately 5,000 were injured during the aforementioned events - 1,200 with eye injuries and many with head injuries, indicating that regime forces assaulted them with intent to kill. The report named a number of political figures, businessmen, and police officers as suspects in those incidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/68627.aspx#comments |title=685 martyrs and more than 5 thousands injured in the events of the revolution ... Involvement of key figures, businessmen and police officers |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date=2010-09-07 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
===Investigations of sectarian violence=== Violence between [[Copts|Coptic Christians]] and Muslims came in the aftermath of a church being set on fire in the village of Sol, near [[Helwan]], south of Cairo. Clashes broke out in the suburbs of Cairo resulting in at least 11 dead and 140 wounded. Muslims allegedly burned the church because of a relationship between a Coptic man and a Muslim woman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewamerican.com/index.php/world-mainmenu-26/africa-mainmenu-27/6655-riots-erupt-in-cairo-after-church-is-burned |title=Riots Erupt in Cairo After Church is Burned |publisher=Thenewamerican.com |date=2011-03-10 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Media in Egypt claimed that former members of the NDP and elements from the [[State Security Investigations Service]] were behind the incident.
==Cases pertaining to individuals== ===Mubarak family=== {{see|Hosni Mubarak|Suzanne Mubarak|Gamal Mubarak|Alaa Mubarak}} On February 28, 2011, Egyptian Prosecutor General Abdel Magid Mahmud put a freeze on the assets of ousted president Hosni Mubarak and his family and imposed a travel ban on them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/mubarak-banned-from-leaving-egypt-assets-frozen-88439 |title=Mubarak banned from leaving Egypt, assets frozen |publisher=Ndtv.com |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Subsequently the Egyptian government asked the U.S. government and the European Union to freeze the assets of the Mubaraks whilst investigating the widespread allegations of profiteering by Mubarak, his wife Suzanne, and their sons Alaa and Gamal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/February/21%20n/Egyptian%20Government%20Wants%20Mubarak%20Family's%20Foreign%20Assets%20Frozen.htm |title=Egyptian Government Wants Mubarak Family's Foreign Assets Frozen |publisher=Aljazeerah.info |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On March 6 Mohamad Hamouda, Mubarak's lawyer during his presidency, stated that he agreed to represent Mubarak on certain conditions, including that the Mubarak family inform him of their exact assets. Hamouda also stated that Mubarak will take legal action against ''The Guardian'' and ''The New York Times'' for defamation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21530&catid=150&Itemid=69 |title=Mohamed Hamouda: Mubarak does not have anything |publisher=Alwafd.org |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On the following day Hamouda withdrew from legal representation for the Mubaraks citing his "discomfort" with the case. Hamouda stated that achieving justice in this case will be difficult and explained that he was given only three days to review evidentiary documents and, two days into this period, he had not yet received these documents from the prosecutor. Hamouda stated that another lawyer, Mourtada Mansour, would represent the Mubaraks. Cairo criminal court was scheduled to start proceedings in this case on March 8, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbashayer.com/news-130937.html |title=Ø¬Ø±ÙØ¯Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨Ø´Ø§ÙØ± | Ø­Ù ÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¹ØªØ°Ø± Ø¹Ù ÙØ¶ÙØ© Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙÙ Ø±ØªØ¶Ù ÙÙØ¨Ù | |publisher=Elbashayer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> On that day neither Mubarak nor his council appeared in court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/8/mobarak_money.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ØªØ¤ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø§Ø± Ø§ÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ù Ø¨Ø§ÙØªØ­ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø£Ù ÙØ§Ù Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙØ£Ø³Ø±ØªÙ |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-08 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The court reaffirmed the travel ban on the Mubarak family and upheld the decision by the prosecutor to freeze the Mubaraks' accounts, citing that there is sufficient evidence to suspect Mubarak and his family of profiteering and misappropriation of public funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/465/2011/03/08/27/66267.aspx |title=Lawyers did not attend it ... Cairo Criminal Endorses the decision of the Attorney General to hold the funds Mubarak and his family |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The Mubaraks were contesting the travel ban in appeals court, while a criminal court was to convene to consider the financial charges.<ref>{{cite web|author=Hamad Al-Chalabi and Fatima Abu Shanab |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289932&IssueID=2069 |title="The police" supports the prevention of Mubarak and his family from their money and "Court of appeal" postpone the disclosure of confidential accounts for today's meeting |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
The general prosecutor, Abdel Magid Mahmud, ordered the financial assets inside Egypt of Mubarak and his family members to be frozen, ''Al Jazeera'' reported. On March 17, 2011, Senator [[John Kerry]], head of the [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]], officially confirmed the U.S. government had frozen assets worth $31 billion belonging to Mubarak, including property and bank accounts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/17/mubarak_usa.aspx |title=Ø¬ÙÙ ÙÙØ±Ù: Ø«Ø±ÙØ© Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù 31.5 Ù ÙÙØ§Ø± Ø¯ÙÙØ§Ø± Ø¨Ø£Ù Ø±ÙÙØ§ ÙØ­Ø¯ÙØ§ |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-17 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
On April 13 the general prosecutor ordered the arrest of former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and his sons, Alaa and Gamal, for 15 days as part of an inquiry into the use of force and violence against pro-democracy demonstrators, and the charges of corruption.<ref>{{cite news|author=Mark Gregory |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13058855 |title=BBC News â Egypt: Mubarak and sons detained amid corruption probe |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 2011-04-13|accessdate=2011-04-14}}</ref>
On June 1, it was announced by the ruling Supreme Military Council of Egypt that Mubarak was due to stand trial on August 3. On July 25, it was decided that the former Interior Minister Habib Al Adly would be put on trial for charges of human rights violations and premeditated murder of protesters during the January 25 Revolution alongside Mubarak and his sons, Alaa and Gamal. There was considerable speculation regarding the issue of whether Mubarak would really stand trial, given the contradictory and controversial reports of his medical status and the perceived prejudice of the ruling Military Council in attempting to prevent Mubarak's trial. However, on August 3, 2011, Mubarak and his sons along with Habib Al Adly did stand trial in the Cairo Police Academy. Mubarak was transported from his hospital at Sharm el Sheikh to Cairo in the early hours of that day on a military aircraft. Egypt awoke in much tension and anticipation at the trial. Clashes were witnessed between pro-Mubarak and anti-Mubarak protesters outside the Police Academy, which were promptly dispersed by the Egyptian police forces. A heavy and concentrated military and security presence was deployed at the trial location, with up to 5000 troops and 500 tanks. Mubarak was placed along with all the defendants in the trial, which included Adly, Mubarak's sons Gamal and Alaa, as well as 6 top aides and associates of Al Adly, in an iron cage as the court proceedings opened. The first day of the trial witnessed an enunciation of the indictment of Mubarak, the accusations and allegations and legal charges directed against him by the Prosecution, which accused him of money laundering, illegally profitting from the sale of natural gas to Israel below international market rates, as well as charges of misappropriation of public funds, sale of state property, and corruption. The Prosecution also asserted that Mubarak had issued instructions to security forces to open fire on demonstrators, which had killed 846 people in the 2011 Egyptian Revolution. Mubarak's lawyer Farid al Deeb countered with outlining his 7 demands, chief among which was his insistence that Mubarak's trial would be separated from Al Adly's, as well as arguing for legal action to be undertaken against Muhammad Hussein Tantawi, the current chairman of the ruling Supreme Military Council, alleging his shared responsibility in Mubarak's crimes. Mubarak and the other defendants were allowed to give their statements in response to the accusations filed against them from the Prosecution, to which all of them replied unequivocally that they categorically denied the charges and accusations directed against them, instead claiming they were innocent. The trial concluded with the decision that judicial proceeedings would be adjourned to August 15.
===Rachid Mohamed Rachid=== [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]] became Egypt's Minister of Foreign Trade and Industry in July 2004. On January 28, 2011, [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] dissolved his then cabinet to form the last cabinet before his ousting. It was reported that Rachid, who was in Dubai at the time of the revolution, was offered a ministerial position in Mubarak's last cabinet which he refused. Rachid became the first high profile figure to be accused of financial irregularities when he was charged while Mubarak was still in office. The timing of the allegations of financial irregularities against Rachid raised some doubts as to whether these allegations were actually disseminated in response to Rachid's refusal to accept an office in Mubarak's last government, or to be scapegoated as the public call for an end to corruption was becoming louder.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-international.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4190:egypt-25-january-revolution-whats-next&catid=45:recent-articles&Itemid=123 |title=Egypt 25 January Revolution: What's next? |publisher=Just-international.org |date=2011-02-09 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
===Habib el-Adly===
The trial of Habib el-Adly follows two streams of legal charges: the first pertains to profiteering activities, and the second pertains to allegations that el-Adly ordered the use of live ammunitions against the demonstrators, during the January 2011 protests in different Egyptian cities, and was responsible for the opening of different jails in Egypt during the protests in order to cause criminal unrest and justify the use of force.<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/25/65906.aspx |title=Al-Adli's Trial postponed to 2nd April and Al-Adli deny charges of profiteering and money laundering from inside the cage |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> A fact-finding panel was formed to assess the responsibility for incidents of criminal unrest. On March 9 the Egyptian daily newspaper ''[[Almasry Alyoum]]'' reported that el-Adly's charges in this case may have been of a political rather than criminal nature; evidence made available to the fact-finding mission suggested that he might have acted on orders from former president Mubarak and not on his own accord.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
El-Adly appeared before the Giza Criminal Court on March 5 where he was formally charged with profiteering and money laundering. These charges relate to allegations that el-Adly received a bribe of 4.5 million Egyptian pounds to allow a contractor to carry out building work on behalf of the Egyptian ministry of interior. El-Adly pleaded not guilty and the court proceedings were adjourned to April 2, to allow el-Adly's council to review the evidence. This trial was described by ''Al-Ahram'' as the "Egyptian trial of the century."<ref name="ahram1"/> El-Adly's police department was widely feared by Egyptians and the allegations, that he was responsible for the widespread thuggery that occurred during and after the Egyptian protests from January 25 to February 12 by opening jails, led to large demonstrations in front of the Giza Courthouse calling for el-Adly's execution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/69C7960A-D11A-4E24-B1DF-E9E155609F0E.htm?GoogleStatID=20 |title=Ø§ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± - Ø¹Ø±Ø¨Ù - Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ ÙÙ Ø«Ù Ø£Ù Ø§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡ Ø§ÙÙ ØµØ±Ù |publisher=Aljazeera.net |date=2011-03-05 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
More details from the investigation of el-Adly were published on March 18 in the ''Dostur'' newspaper, which reported that el-Adly described his subordinates and the political leadership of Egypt of having used him as a scapegoat. He reportedly alleged that the decision to deal with the demonstrations was a joint decision involving the political leadership, including Mubarak, who called for ending the anti-regime demonstrations at any price.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/18/38402 |title=Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ:ÙØ±Ø§Ø± Ø§ÙØªØ¹Ø¯Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ ØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ Ø¬Ø§Ø¡ Ù Ù Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù Ø§ÙØ°Ù Ø·ÙØ¨ ÙØ¶ Ø§ÙØ§Ø­ØªØ¬Ø§Ø¬Ø§Øª Ø¨Ø£Ù Ø·Ø±ÙÙØ© | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-18 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
===Anas el-Fiqqi=== [[Anas el-Fiqqi]] was the Minister of Youth and subsequently became the Minister of Information from February 2004 to February 2011.<ref>Magda El-Ghitany, [http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2006/776/sc2.htm The honest chameleon], ''[[Al-Ahram Weekly]]'', 5â11 January 2006</ref> He was implicated in the harassment of journalists during the 2011 Egyptian revolution and for the closure of news channels such as [[Al Jazeera]] in [[Cairo]].<ref>[http://www.silobreaker.com/egyptian-information-ministry-shuts-down-aljazeera-channel-in-egypt-5_2264323710687117323 ]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref> On February 12, the day after the president stepped down, he resigned and was reportedly placed under [[house arrest]].<ref>{{cite news|author=David Batty |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/feb/12/egypt-day-after-mubarak-quits |title=Egypt the day after Mubarak quits â live | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-02-12|accessdate=2011-03-23 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/12/live-blog-feb-13-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 13 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-02-12 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> El-Fiqqi was charged with financial irregularities and became subject to investigations. His detention was renewed for 15 days on March 9 for further investigation of reports that he misappropriated funds, used public funds to support the NDP and for personal purchases, and received a bribe to allocate the advertising rights from an Arab media festival to the nephew of Mubarak's office manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/9/fekki_shekh.aspx |title=ØªØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø¨Ø³ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ ÙØ§ÙØ´ÙØ® 15 ÙÙÙ Ø§ |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-09 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
===Ahmed El-Maghrabi=== In February 2011 Maghrabi was accused of wasting public money and seizing state land following a cabinet purge by then President [[Hosni Mubarak]].<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/07/us-egypt-adli-idUSTRE7163D420110207 Egypt's ex-police chief appears before prosecutors]</ref>
===Zoheir Garana=== On March 6 the Egyptian daily newspaper ''Alwafd'' reported that the Prosecutor General of Egypt referred Zoheir Garana, the tourism minster in Mubarak's regime, to a Cairo criminal court on suspicions of [[embezzlement]] and [[profiteering]]. Garana was accused of misusing public funds amounting to 51 million [[Egyptian pound]]s. It is noteworthy that Garana was arrested and placed on [[remand]] more than a week before the court referral order was issued by the Prosecutor General.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21341:Ø¥Ø­Ø§ÙØ©-Ø¬Ø±Ø§ÙØ©-ÙØ§ÙØ­Ø§Ø°Ù-ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§ÙÙ-ÙÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª&catid=150:Ø«ÙØ±Ø©%20Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨&Itemid=409</ref> Garana has not formally been put on trial, but rather detained in Tora Prison on suspicions concerning the scapegoating of officials, differential or preferential justice. As with many of those charged in the aftermath of the Egyptian Revolution, Garana's decisions and actions were seen as compliant with the policies set by the government in which he served.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} The 51 million Garana is accused of misusing refers to the sale of a five million square meter piece of land in Ein el-Sokhna. Mr. Garana sealed the deal in accordance to a presidential decree made on July 4, 2005, where the price was $1 per meter.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} It is claimed that Garana alloted pieces of land at a low price to a company he owns, "Royal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/21/38583 |title=ØªØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø¨Ø³ Ø²ÙÙØ± Ø¬Ø±Ø§ÙØ© 15 ÙÙÙ Ø§Ù ÙÙ ÙØ¶Ø§ÙØ§ Ø§ÙØªØ±Ø¨ÙØ­ ÙØ§ÙØ§Ø³ØªÙÙØ§Ø¡ Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ù | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
==Concerns== ===Judiciary=== On March 21 ''Alwafd'' reported that the possibility of a deal between the prosecution and some of those accused of embezzlement was explored. ''Alwafd'' stated that this option was explored after the prosecution was successful in striking a deal with some creditors and business borrowers to repay a total of 13 billion Egyptian pounds in return for dropping legal charges. The situation, according to ''Alwafd'', proved more complex as the offers made by the accused, in return for dropping the embezzlement charges, were seen as unrealistic.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25966:Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø±Ø§Ø¡-Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ÙØ§-Ø±Ø¯-Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¨ÙÙ-ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø©-Ø±ÙØ¶Øª&catid=98:Ù Ø­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=92</ref>
===Public opinion=== Concerns were raised that the accused would not be treated fairly due to the overwhelming public opinion against them. In an interview with the ''Shabab Alahram'' newspaper a well-known Egyptian lawyer, Mohamed Hamoouda, stated that his decision to withdraw from Hosni Mubarak's council was triggered by his belief that justice will not be achieved in these cases (see above under Mubarak's case). On March 8 Hamouda argued that these cases should be deferred until a later stage to ensure better administration of justice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://shabab.ahram.org.eg/Inner.aspx?ContentID=4245&typeid=1&year=2010&month=04&day=04&issueid=6 |title=Mubarak's lawyer: the judiciary will pass judgment condemning the former president to appease the people |publisher=Shabab.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
===Embezzlement vs. human rights abuse charges=== The first wave of legal actions following Mubarak's resignation was dominated by charges of financial nature, including bribery, misappropriation of funds, profiteering, [[embezzlement]] and money laundering. This caused concerns, particularly in the case of [[Habib el-Adly]] whose public image was much more eroded by allegations of human rights abuses, yet only faced legal charges over financial matters during the first wave of legal action. On March 16 the families of some of the protesters killed by the police demonstrated in front of the office of the general prosecutor of Egypt for what they saw as exclusive focus on financial cases at the expense of human rights cases. Some of these families claimed that the legal files pertaining to their slain relatives were not yet received by the prosecution.<ref>90 Minutes, Al-Mehwar TV, March 17, 2011</ref>
===Allegations of concealment and disposal of evidentiary documents=== On March 5-6 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org"/> The fires, which occurred at several state security offices, were witnessed the day after the government of [[Ahmed Shafik]], the last minister appointed by Mubarak, had resigned. Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in the various state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com"/> The demonstrators reportedly found some documents, CDs, video and audiotape recordings pertaining to a number of recent events in Egypt, including the explosion in the Two Saints Church in Alexandria on December 31, 2010, in which the state security apparatus, under el-Adly, was allegedly involved. Documents pertaining to spying, blackmailing and torture activities were also found and handed over to the state prosecutor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/38/65967.aspx |title=Fires within the state security headquarters ''(burning of documents and papers)''! Simultaneous attacks on the headquarters are terrifying |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
On March 6, 2011, it was reported that among the documents that were found in a readable condition in the Egyptian State Security buildings, was a file from the office of Hassan Abdulrahman. As the former deputy interior minster under Mubarak he gave instructions to various branches of Egyptian State Security buildings to shred archived documents. These documents were believed to contain relevant information to the widespread allegations of human rights abuses by the Egyptian State Security.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21420:Ù ÙÙ-Ù Ø¤Ø§Ù Ø±Ø©-Ø£Ù Ù-Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ©&catid=144:Ù ÙÙØ§Øª%20Ù Ø­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=337</ref> In an interview with [[BBC]] Arabic TV on March 7 General F. Allam, previous deputy director of the Egyptian State Security, stated that the burning of these documents will not impact on the evidence required for any court case - as copies of all these documents are automatically archived in confidential locations. General Allam argued that an order might have indeed been issued to shred or burn the documents due to fears that they may fall "in the wrong hands" if state security buildings were stormed by demonstrators.<ref>BBC Arabic: Interview with Sakina Fouad, General F Allam, and Mr Wael, a representative of the demonstrators, March 7, 2011</ref> The same day of the interview 47 officers from the Egyptian State Security were arrested on suspicions of involvement in damaging these documents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elbashayer.com/news-131011.html |title=Ø¬Ø±ÙØ¯Ø© Ø§ÙØ¨Ø´Ø§ÙØ± | Ø­Ø¨Ø³ 47 Ø¶Ø§Ø¨Ø· Ø§Ù Ù Ø¯ÙÙØ© Ø­Ø±ÙÙØ§ ÙØ«Ø§Ø¦Ù Ø®Ø·ÙØ±Ø© | |publisher=Elbashayer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
